title: How is the high E string two octaves higher than the low E string in a guitar? - Quora

response.answer_text: Original question: How is the high E string two octaves higher than the low E string in a guitar? For this, you need to know your scales right. The low E string is followed by the A string, which in turn is followed by the D string. On the D string’s third fret you will find another E. This E is one octave higher than the low E string. Proceeding similarly, there’s only a range of one octave between the D string’s second fret and the high E string. So in all, the Low E string is a couple of octaves lower than the high E.

Start Going major scale from any note or open low e, u will reach end of the octave that is E3, i.e. E one octave higher than low E on two frets up on D string, from there one more run is needed to reach to the high E making it one octave higher than this one, hence overall two octaves higher than low E
